titlestmt.title: PCT 39: A Bony Spectre Abducts a Woman
titlestmt.author: Adam Sakewew

bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: PCT 39 : A bony spectre abducts a woman

p.seg: nêhiyaw pêyak , osîma oskinîkiwa . A certain Cree had a younger brother, a mere youth.
awa ostêsimâw pêyakoyiwa okosisa . The elder brother had one son.
mistah âhkosiyiwa , êh-apisîsisit awa nâpêsis . This little boy fell very sick.
êkwah atoskêmôw , ayîsiyiniwah êh-atotât . The man sought medical aid, employing people to use their power.
mâskôc awa kâ-sâkihak nikosis kita-nipiw , itêyihtam . “Perhaps my beloved son is to die,” he thought.

kîtahtawê aw ôskinîkiw , ostêsah ê-sêkisiyit ,
mahtih , nistêsê , wâpatonisk miyin , itêw ostêsa . Then at one time that youth whose brother was in fear, said to him, “Come, Brother, give me some white paint-clay.”
miyik . He gave him some.
piyisk misiwê wâpatonisk astêw . Then he put the white clay all over his body.

âta êh-âhkosiyit okosisiwâwa , otinêw , ê-wayawîhtahât aw oskinîkiw . Although their son was ill, the youth took him up, and carried him out of the tent. LB: “Their son”: father's brother and mother's sister use the terms, “my son” and “my daughter” more often than the specific {nikosim}, {nitôsim}; the distinction between these is unknown to me; Lacombe's statement (Dict. 669f.) is confused.
êh-pîhtokahât ôh âwâsisah , miyw-âyâyiwa . When he brought the child in again, he was well.

êkosi kîtahtawê wîwiw ; tâpiskôc wîwiwak ostêsa . Then, in the course of time, he took a wife; he took his wife from the same family as had his elder brother. LB: Literally, “they had wives in the same way”; the interpretation in the text is a surmise.
hâw , nisîm , atâwâkanak nôcihâtân ; paskêpicitân , itêw osîma . “Come, Younger Brother, let us go in pursuit of furs; let us move camp away from the band,” he said to his younger brother.
êhag , itik . “Yes,” the latter answered him.
âsay otawâsimisiwak aw ôskinîkiw ; misikitiyiwa , êh-pimitâcimoyit . The youth and his wife had by this time a child; it was of a size to be crawling about.
kîtahtawê êh-mâcîcik , êkwah awa iskwêw nikohtêw . Then at one time, as they were hunting, that woman gathered wood.
kîtahtawê wanihâw . Then, at one time, she was missed.
namoya takosin . She did not come home.
kîtahtawê êh-tipiskâyik , êkâ êh-takosihk , ntonikêwak ostêsah . Presently, as darkness fell and she did not arrive, the youth and his brother searched.
namoya miskawêwak ; namoya mâtâhêwak . They did not find her; they did not come upon her tracks.
mâskôc nipiw sisikoc , itêyihtamwak . “Perhaps she suddenly died,” they thought.
êkwah ostêsah saskahamawêw . Then he offered his elder brother a lighted pipe.

seg.gloss: “My, elder brother, try to know about your sister-in-law.

p.seg: kikosisinaw mistahi mâtôw , itêw . Our son is crying much,” he told him.
êhag , itik . “Very well,” the other answered him.
nikamôw . He sang.

seg.q: nisîm , ôtah ômêskanaw awa nîtim pikoh niwâpahtên , êkotah oma kâ-ntonikêyahk .
seg.gloss: “My younger brother, here I see only the path of my sister-in-law, even there where we made search.

seg.q: namoya nântaw ntisi-wâpahtên ta-misi-wanâtisit awa nîtim ka-wanihâyahk .
seg.gloss: Not in any way do I see that my sister-in-law whom we have lost has gone to her ruin.”

p.seg: wiyaskinahêw aw ôstêsimâw . The elder brother filled a pipe.
êkwah miyâw ospwâkana . He gave the other the pipe.

seg.gloss: “My younger brother, smoke this.
Try to find my sister-in-law.
She has not been destroyed.

p.seg: mâskôc kêkway kikiskêyihtên , itêw osîma . Perhaps you have some mystic power,” he said to his younger brother.
êkwah pîhtwâw aw oskinîkiw . Then the youth smoked.
kêtayôwinisêw . He took off his clothes.
êkwah itohtêw itah kâ-nikohtêyit owîkimâkanah . Then he went to where his wife had gathered wood.
êkwah êh-pipohk ; omayikohk ositah kaskitênam ; êkwah ôhi ocihciyah kaskitênam aw ôskinîkiw . It was winter; he blackened his feet, here; and he blackened his hands, the youth.
êkwah itohtêw ; êy-otihtahk owîkimâkanah itah ê-kîh-nikohtêyit , ntonikêw . Then he went there; when he came to where his wife had gathered firewood, he searched.

kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk itah êh-kîh-nîpawiyit owîkimâkanah ; itah ê-tahkoskêyit êkotah nîpaww . Presently he saw a place where his wife had stood; upon the imprints of her feet he placed his feet, as he stood.
itah êh-ayîtiskêyit , êkotah tahkoskêw aw oskinîkiw . Upon the imprints of her feet, as she had gone, step after step, the youth placed his feet, as he walked.
pahkêkin akwanahôw ; êyako piko mosêskatêw . He had a skin wrapped round him; but for this garment he was unclothed.
êkwah tahkoskêw itah ê-kîh-tahkoskêyit owîkimâkanah . Then he made his steps wherever his wife had set foot.

kîtahtawê êkotah ohci êh-itâpit , pôt ôma tâpiskôc pîsimwêyâpiy isinâkwaniyiw ômêskanaw aw îskwêw , nayêwac ê-pimakocihk . Presently, as he looked on ahead, lo, there, like a rainbow looked the trail of that woman, as she had left the ground and floated through the air.
ohpîw awa oskinîkiw . The youth took off from the ground.
nayêwac pimakocin , tâpiskôc êh-pimihât . He floated through the air as though he were flying.

pôtih wâhyaw êh-ayât , pôtih minahikwâhtikwa êh-nawêyâskosiniyit , êkotah êsah kâh-nipâyit , namoya tâpwê êh-nipât , êh-owîcimosit anihi kâ-sipwêhtahikot . Behold, when he had gone a long ways, where a pine tree lay across the path, there she must have slept, - not that she had really slept, but where she had taken for her lover him who had abducted her.
êkotah ohci ohpiyiwa . From there she had again risen aloft.
ohpîw wista , êkwah êh-pimakocihk nayêwac . He too rose aloft, gliding again through the air.
kîtahtawê k-âti-nîhtakociniyit . Presently she had again gone down to the ground.
ati-nîhtakocin wîstah . He, too, at that point, went down to the ground.
kîtahtawê mohcihk êkwah ati-pimohtêyiwa , ê-sêskisiyit minahikoskâhk . Then she had walked on, on the earth, and had gone into a wood of pines.
pôti kâ-wâpahtahk wîstêpahkwayikamik êh-mâyâtaniyik , êh-misâyik . There he beheld a large and ugly tent of old leather rags.
kotak wâpahtam êh-apisâsiniyik . He saw another and smaller one.
êkwah pîhtokêw . Then he entered.
pôt ôhi kîh-apiyiwa wêskwâhtêmihk ; kotakah nâpêwah pimitakâm apiyiwa . Lo, there they sat, opposite the doorway; another man sat across the lodge from them.
kik-apiyiwa owîkimâkana , ê-wîtapimâyit pâkahkosah . There sat his wife, sitting by the side of a bony spectre.

awa pimitakâm k-âpit , êwako tapâhtiskwêyiw kotak pâkahkos , êh-ostêsit awa pâkahkos kâ-kimotit iskwêwa . That other bony spectre who sat aross the lodge, lowered his head; and he was the elder brother of him who had stolen the woman.
êkwah aw oskinîkiw pimohtêw , pâskisikan apasôhk êh-takopitêyik , ê-wâpihtakâyik ; Then that youth walked over to where a gun hung from the lodgepole; it looked like a bleached stick; he thought,
pâskisikan pôt ôma ! wîsta nika-otinên oma pâskisikan ; nîst âyako nik-âyân ! itêyihtam . “So this is a gun! From him, in turn, I shall take the gun; I, in turn, shall have it!”
êkwah êy-otinahk , pimakocin aw îskwêwa kâ-kimotit pâkahkos , êh-pâhpit . As he took it, that bony spectre who had stolen the woman, came reaching for it, with a peal of laughter.

seg.gloss: “My follow-husband, let go of this my gun!
I love this gun of mine!

p.seg: kîwinaw kîwêhtah ! itwêw awa pâkahkos . Take back our wife!” said the bony spectre.

seg.gloss: “No! You took her, when I, too, loved her.
Now I will take a thing you love.
That is why I have come to take your gun.
When I loved her who is your wife, you came and took her.
So now I cannot have her to wife.”

p.seg: â , nikosâk , kiyâm miyin nipâskisikan ; mistahi nisâkihtân ! itwêw awa pâkahkos . “Oh, Fellow-Husband, please, give me my gun; I prize it too highly!” cried the bony spectre.

seg.gloss: “I shall not by any chance give it to you.”
“If you wish, never will you fail of any game.
You will be good at killing every kind of beast.
Always I shall go at your side.”

p.seg: namoya ! itwêw awa oskinîkiw . “No!” said the youth.
êkwah aw ôstêsimâw wayawîw , ohtâwiya êh-ntawi-ntomât . Then that elder one went out of the tent to call his father.
pôt âwa kisêyiniw pâkahkos pîhtokêw . The old man Koshtchey entered.

seg.gloss: “Alas, my children have stood facing each other!
seg.note: LB: Literally, “they have stood in relation to each other, by each other”, but the actual meaning is unknown to me.

seg.gloss: Although often, 'Do not take a woman of the common, mortal men,' I said to my son; 'Of manitou nature are real men,' though I told him more than once, when I instructed him, yet none the less he did so, robbing, as if none other would serve, one who had a husband, this stubborn fool of mine, who does not heed my words.
seg.note: LB: As the powers of spirit beings seem to us unusual, so ours to them. Cf. the same sentence in Jones' _Fox Texts_, 108, 15.

seg.q: - nkosis , êkos âwa êh-tâpwêt , awa kikosâk kây-isi-wîhtamâsk .
seg.gloss: - My son, even thus he speaks true, this thy fellow-husband, in what he has told thee.
All night we will teach thee songs and how to do.
Pray, hear me with pity.
We greatly prize our guns.
This one here, your kinsman now, obeys my word;
seg.note: LB on {kiciwâm}: Thus it appears that {niciwâm}: “my brother (man speaking(” has, among its many uses that of “my fellow-husband's brother.”

seg.q: tânisi êh-itak tôtam , awa kikosâk ê-kakêpâtisit , kâ-ntawi-kimotamâsk kiwîkimâkanah .
seg.gloss: as I tell him, he does, while he, your fellow-husband is foolish and stubborn, and thus has gone and stolen your wife from you.
But in this he spoke true which he told you.”
“Very well.
Do not speak false.

p.seg: awa nka-kîwêhtahâw kîwinaw , itwêw aw ôskinîkiw . I shall take home with me this wife of ours,” said the youth.

seg.gloss: “So be it.”

seg.q: pêyakotipiskwa pikoh ôtah nik-âyânân ; wâpahki nka-kîwânân awa kistim .
seg.gloss: “One night only we shall stay here; tomorrow your daughter-in-law here and I shall go home.”
seg.note: LB on {pêyakotipiskwa}: Not to be divided by hyphen; {-tipiskwa} (particle) and {-tipiskwê-} (verb) are the non-initial (suffixal) forms corresponding to {tipisk} and {tipiskwâw}. Similarly, {kîsikâw}: “it is day” has the odd non-initial verb-forming suffix {-kîsihkwê-}.

seg.gloss: “There, Kinsman, I thank you for having lent ear to him who is now your father as well as ours.
Because you have done me this favor, never shall mortal man be lost to you.

seg.q: iyâhkosicih , kika-pmâcihâw ; ahpôh awâsis , iskwêw , nama wîhkâc ka-kîhikon kita-pimâcihat .
seg.gloss: Whenever one is sick, you shall restore him to life; be it a child, a woman, never shall he be beyond your power of restoring him to life.
There, brother, this is my gift to you.

seg.q: kikosâk minahôwin kiwîhtamâk , ta-wahkêh-nipahtâyin kêkway pisiskiwak .
seg.gloss: Your fellow-husband promised you the killing of game, of every kind of beast.”

p.seg: êkos îtik . Thus he spoke to him.

seg.q: êkwah niya , nkosis , mahtâhitôwin kik-êsiyîhkâtên ; êwako niya kimiyitin .
seg.gloss: “And I, my son, Potlatch you will call it; this is what I give to you.
Give me fat to eat, when you arrive at your home.

seg.q: êkotah cîkih kâ-wîkiyêk nîso môswak kimiyitin , kit-âsamiyin , êkotah ohci pimiy kit-ôtinaman .
seg.gloss: Close by to where you dwell, two moose I give you, that you may feed me, that you may take the fat from them.

seg.q: êkosi awa kiciwâm k-êtwêt , êkosi nîsta kitisi-miyitin .
seg.gloss: And even as your brother said, even such a gift I too am giving you.”

p.seg: êhag , itêw . “So be it,” he said.
êkwah nikamohik okosâka . Then his fellow-husband taught him songs.
piyisk wâpaniyiw . At last day dawned.
ê-kîsi-nikamohikot , êh-wâpaniyik , wayawîwak owîkimâkanah aw oskinîkiw . When he had been taught the songs, and day had come, the youth and his wife went from that tent.
pâkahkos wayawîw mîna , êh-wîcêwât okosâka . The bony spectre, too, went out, to escort his fellow-husband.

seg.q: hâw , nikosâk , êkâya kotakah nâpêwah kit-âyâwêw kîwinaw .
seg.gloss: “Very well, Fellow-Husband; let not our wife have dealings with other men.
I give you a full span of life.
And our son, too, shall live a full span of life.

seg.q: tâpwê êkâ wiya wîhkâc kita-mâmawîhitôw kîwinaw ; nkâhkwêyihtaskin .
seg.gloss: But see to it that our wife never be guilty of adultery; I am jealous in marriage.”

p.seg: êkosi kîwêwak owîkimâkanah . So he and his wife went home.
takohtêwak wîkiwâhk . They reached their dwelling.
posko-kîsik mâcîw aw oskinîkiw . That same day the youth hunted.

kahkiyaw otinam pimiyah oskanihk ohci , êkwah êwako êh-asamât ohtâwiya , ociwâma , okosâka . he took all the marrow from the bones, and made of it an offering to his adoptive father and brother and to his fellow-husband.
êkwah aspin êy-ispayik namoy âcimôw aw ôskinîkiw . And the youth did not tell of what had happened from the time he went away.
namoya kakwêcimêw osîma awa nâpêw . That man did not question his younger brother.

seg.q: tânis êtokê tiyôtahk awa nisîm , kâ-pêsiwât owîkimâkanah !
seg.gloss: “I wonder how my younger brother did, to bring back his wife!

p.seg: kêhcinâ mantôww awa nisîm ! itêyihtam aw ostêsimâw . Surely my younger brother has manitou power!” thought the elder brother.

êkwah ôhô okosisiwâwa tân-tahtw askiy êh-wih-ohpikiyit , kîtahtawê êh-kwâpikêt aw îskwêw , kotakah nâpêwa kâ-kitotât , êh-mamawîhtot . Then when that son of theirs, after I know not how many years, was nearly grown, then at one time, when that woman was fetching water, she had converse with another man, and committed adultery.
êh-kîwêt , awiya kâ-pakamahokot otihtimanihk . As she went home, someone struck her on the shoulder.
êkosi sêmâk âhkosiw . Then at once she became ill.
mayaw êh-âhkosiyit , awa nâpêw atoskêmôw , ta-nânapâcihimiht owîkimâkanah . As soon as she fell sick, that man called in doctors, that his wife might have treatment.
êkotah ohci kiskêyihtam êh-pakamahomiht owîkimâkanah . In this way he learned that his wife had been struck.
kakwêcimêw . He questioned her.

seg.gloss: “I had been having a talk with that young man.

seg.q: êkosi êh-pê-kîwêyân , êkotah kâ-pasastêwokawiyân ntihtimanihk ; êwak ohci k-âhkosiyân .
seg.gloss: Then, as I was coming home, I was struck with a stick or switch on my shoulder; from that I am sick.”

p.seg: piyisk kêkâc nipiw aw îskwêw mihcêtwayak êh-atoskêmohk . At last that woman was close to death, though many kinds of doctoring were tried.
piyisk awa aw ôskinîkiw kâ-wîwit ostêsah miyik ospwâkanah , kita-pîhtwât . At last the youth whose wife she was, was given a pipe by his elder brother, that he smoke.

seg.gloss: “Try to treat my sister-in-law, Younger Brother.
All kinds of treatment have already been given her.”

p.seg: hâw , ôma kâ-sakâk êkotah osîhtâk têsipicikan , itwêw aw oskinîkiw . “Very well, over in that grove set up a scaffold,” said the youth.
êkosi osîhtâwân têsipicikan . Accordingly a scaffold was built for him.
êkwah êh-tipiskâyik , êkotê itohtahâw aw îskwêw k-âhkosit . Then, at nightfall, the sick woman was taken there.

êh-kîwêcik , namwâc cêskwah otihtam awa wîkiwâw , awa oskinîkiw , awa mîna ostêsimâw , âsay itah wîtimwah k-âkociniyit , êkotah âsay kâ-matwêwêyit , ê-sâkowêwiht . When they went back home, that youth with his elder brother had not yet reached their dwelling-place, when already, from where the latter's sister-in-law lay high on the scaffold, there came the report of a gun, and they heard shouting. LB on {kâ-matwêwêyit}: If correctly recorded, an animate form, my impression is, however, that {-wêwê-}: “noise” forms only inanimate verbs; if so, we should read {matwêwêyik}.
nikosâk , kîwinaw pê-nâs ; âsay pimâtisiw , itâw . “My fellow-husband, come get our wife; already she is cured,” he was told.
itohtêw kâwi aw oskinîkiw . The youth went back there.
kahkiyaw pêhtawâw awa pâkahkos tânisi êh-itwêt . Everything was heard which that bony spectre said.
pôtih wêtihtât owîkimâkanah , âsay nîhtakosiyiwa . When he reached his wife, she was already climbing down.
kîwêhtahêw . He took her home.
êh-takohtêt wîkiwâhk , âsay miyw-ayâw aw îskwêw , mistahi ka-kîh-âhkosit . When she reached their dwelling, she was already well, sick as she had been.
êkosi êkotah ohcih kiskêyimâw aw ôskinîkiw êh-mamâhtâwisit . So then from this the youth was known to have magic powers.
êkosi aw êh-pimâtisit aw îskwêw . Thus this woman was restored to life.
êkosi êkwah aw oskinîkiw mâhtahitôwinihkêw . And then that youth arranged a potlatch ceremony.
êkosi kostâw êkwah , ê-mantôwit êh-itêyimiht . And then he was feared, because he was thought to have spirit power.
namoya awiya nôcihkamâk . And his wife was not wooed by any man.
êkwah êkotah kâw-ohcipayik nêhiyawak ê-mahtâhitocik . And from this it came that the Cree have the potlatch.
êkoyikohk iskwâw âcimowin . Here ends the story.
